00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserSolutionFor.pl - An answer checker that checks if a student's answer
00020 satisifies an implicit equation.
00021 
00022 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00023 
00024 This is a Parser class that implements an answer checker that
00025 checks if a student's answer satisfies an implicit equation.
00026 We define a SolutionFor object class that lets you specify an
00027 equality that the student answer must satisfy, and a point that
00028 DOES satify the equation.  The overloaded == operator will
00029 check if a given point satisfies the given equality.
00030 
00031 Use SolutionFor(equality,point[,options]) to create a SolutionFor object.
00032 The equality is a Formula object containing an equality, or a string
00033 representing such a formula, and the point is a Point object or string
00034 containing a point that satisfies the equation (to be used as the
00035 correct answer when the student asks to see the answers).
00036 
00037 The variables to use are declared in the Context in the usual way,
00038 and the coordinates of the student point will be considered to be in
00039 alphabetical order.  You can override this by supplying the vars=>[...]
00040 option, where you specify the variable names in the order you want the
00041 student to give them.  E.g., vars=>['y','x'] will make the student answer
00042 represent the point (y,x) rather than the default (x,y).
00043 
00044 Usage examples:
00045 
00046     Context("Vector")->variables->are(x=>'Real',y=>'Real');
00047     $f = SolutionFor("x^2 = cos(y)","(1,0)");
00048     $f = SolutionFor("x^2 - y = 0",[2,4]);
00049     $f = SolutionFor("x^2 - y = 0",Point(4,2),vars=>['y','x']);
00050 
00051 Then use
00052 
00053     ANS($f->cmp);
00054 
00055 to get the answer checker for $f.
00056 
00057 You can use $f->{f} to get the Formula object for the equality used
00058 in the object, and $f->f(point) to determine if the given point is
00059 a solution to the equality or not.  For example, if you want to include
00060 the TeX version of a formula within the text of a problem, you can use:
00061 
00062     Context()->texStrings;
00063     BEGIN_TEXT
00064     A solution to \($f->{f}\) is \((x,y)\) = \{ans_rule(30)\}.
00065     END_TEXT
00066     Context()->normalStrings;
00067     ANS($f->cmp);
00068 
00069 =cut
00070 
00071 loadMacros("MathObjects.pl");
00072 
00073 sub _parserSolutionFor_init {}; # don't reload this file
00074 
00075 #
00076 #  Create a SolutionFor object of the correct type
00077 #
00078 sub SolutionFor {
00079   #
00080   #  Get the professor's equation
00081   #
00082   my $context = SolutionFor::getContext();     # use a context in which equality is defined
00083   my $f = main::Formula($context,shift);       # get equation as a formula
00084 
00085   #
00086   #  Get the professor's correct point
00087   #
00088   my $p = shift; $p = main::Point($p) if ref($p) eq "ARRAY";
00089   $p = main::Compute($p) unless Value::isValue($p);
00090 
00091   #
00092   #  Get any user options (e.g., vars => ['x','y'])
00093   #
00094   my %options = (vars=>undef,@_);
00095 
00096   #
00097   #  Do some error checking
00098   #
00099   Value::Error("Your formula doesn't look like an implicit equation")
00100      unless $f->type eq 'Equality';
00101   Value::Error("Professor's answer should be a point or a number")
00102      unless Value::isNumber($p) || $p->type eq 'Point';
00103 
00104   #
00105   #  Save the formula for future reference, and make a callable
00106   #  perl function out of it.
00107   #
00108   $p->{f} = $f;
00109   $p->{F} = $f->perlFunction(undef,$options{vars});
00110 
00111   #
00112   #  Save some data about the original object
00113   #  and make the Value package think we are one of its objects
00114   #
00115   $p->{originalClass} = $p->cmp_class;
00116   $p->{isValue} = 1;
00117 
00118   #
00119   #  Make the object into the correct SolutionFor subclass
00120   #
00121   $p = bless $p, "SolutionFor::".$p->class;
00122 
00123   #
00124   #  Make sure professor's answer actually works
00125   #
00126   Value::Error("Professor's answer of %s does not satisfy the given equation",$p->string)
00127     unless $p->f($p);
00128 
00129   #
00130   #  Return the SolutionFor object
00131   #
00132   return $p;
00133 }
00134 
00135 ######################################################################
00136 #
00137 #  Define the new class (we make subclasses below)
00138 #  (we need subclasses in order to make things work
00139 #  properly with single-variable complex or real-valued
00140 #  equations)
00141 #
00142 package SolutionFor;
00143 
00144 #
00145 #  Evaluate the formula on the given point
00146 #
00147 sub f {
00148   my $self = shift;
00149   &{$self->{F}}(shift->value);
00150 }
00151 
00152 #
00153 #  The name of this object for error messages
00154 #
00155 sub cmp_class {shift->{originalClass}}
00156 
00157 #
00158 #  Do a comparison by testing if the formula's equality
00159 #  operation returns true or false.
00160 #  (Since we are implementing <=> here, we need
00161 #  to return 0 when true and 1 when false.)
00162 #
00163 sub compare {
00164   my ($l,$r) = @_;
00165   $r = Value::makeValue($r,context=>$l->context);
00166   return ($l->f($r)) ? 0 : 1;
00167 }
00168 
00169 #
00170 #  Set up a new context that is a copy of the current one, but
00171 #  has the equality operator defined, and the SolutionFor object
00172 #  prededence set so that comparisons with points or numbers will
00173 #  be promoted to comparisons with the SolutionFor
00174 #
00175 sub getContext {
00176   my $oldContext = main::Context();
00177   $oldContext->{precedence}{SolutionFor} = $oldContext->{precedence}{special};
00178   my $context = $oldContext->copy;
00179   Parser::BOP::equality->Allow($context);
00180   return $context
00181 }
00182 
00183 ######################################################################
00184 #
00185 #  A separate class for Reals, to get Value::Real in the ISA list
00186 #
00187 package SolutionFor::Real;
00188 our @ISA = qw(SolutionFor Value::Real Value);
00189 
00190 #
00191 #  Pass the real number directly
00192 #
00193 sub f {
00194   my $self = shift;
00195   &{$self->{F}}(shift);
00196 }
00197 
00198 
00199 ######################################################################
00200 #
00201 #  A separate class for Complexes
00202 #
00203 package SolutionFor::Complex;
00204 our @ISA = qw(SolutionFor Value::Complex Value);
00205 
00206 #
00207 #  Pass the complex number directly
00208 #
00209 sub f {
00210   my $self = shift;
00211   &{$self->{F}}(shift);
00212 }
00213 
00214 ######################################################################
00215 #
00216 #  A separate class for Points
00217 #
00218 package SolutionFor::Point;
00219 our @ISA = qw(SolutionFor Value::Point Value);
00220 
00221 #
00222 #  Use the Point's defaults, but turn off coordinate hints
00223 #  (since a wrong coordinate isn't detectable)
00224 #
00225 sub cmp_defaults {(
00226   shift->SUPER::cmp_defaults,
00227   showCoordinateHints => 0,
00228 )}
00229 
00230 1; # make Perl happy
